comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: OSI map centered on the photographers approximate position. note crane and SP. maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,605395,790263,7,9

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: Very evocative photo with the winter sun. No.6T was one of the ex Tralee & Dingle Railway locomotives, transferred firstly to the West Clare section after closure of the Tralee system in 1952, and finally moving to the Cavan & Leitrim in 1957 to deal with the increasing coal traffic from the Arigna mines. Its sister locomotive 5T is currently in a dismantled state in Tralee.

comment.author: 41996436@N08
comment._content: Built by the Hunslet Engine Company, Jack Lane, Hunslet, Leeds, West Yorkshire, in 1898.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Nobody seems to have commented on the Squishing event which must have been very colourful!!!  We had a number of one time shutters in our family who would be appalled at our levity:-)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The Great Squishing Drama of '59 limerick I'll wager a Pound or a Punt - The good folk performing this shunt Were not in a squish Whatever you wish - It's only a cunning old stunt.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content:
Shunters used a long hooked pole to connect 3-link couplings on Standard Gauge waggons.
Express train carriages were more dangerous. They stood in the station with their brakes on. The driver backed up his loco to compress the buffers. The shunter dropped down from the platform and under the buffers to connect the screw couplings and vacuum pipes.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Thanks! I never realized trains had vacuum brakes. D'oh!

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Carriages with vacuum brakes persisted long after steam locos had finished in the UK. Many other railways in the world used Westinghouse air brakes. The narrow gauge loco above has a "Meatchopper" coupling. I saw these couplings on the WAGR in Perth WA back in the 1970s. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norwegian_coupling

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach/] Shunters were known to slip their pole in over and under parts of the carriage and sitting on it hitch a ride up and down the yard.  It was risky but if they felt sure of the pole they would take the chance.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content:
A sound we will not hear again - 
Imagine a long line of loose-coupled waggons. The loco driver opens up too quickly.
The shock wave travels through the buffers all the way to the guards van and knocks the guard off his feet. The shock wave then reflects back to the loco.
I have seen buffers jump over each other this way.
